description.raw:
This builds on the double pendulum example using bullet in pull request #13. This example uses `btMultiBody`, which uses generalized coordinates for representing rigid bodies and Featherstone’s algorithm for simulation. 

Note that I changed the test for quaternion equality to check if the dot product of the quaternions is ±1. Otherwise, this implementation matches the error tolerances of the DART example, which leads me to believe that the errors in the bullet implementation in #13 may not be due to floating point precision.

Also note that I did not create collision shapes. They didn’t seem necessary for the simple demonstration we’re aiming for and Bullet seems to work fine without them.

Otherwise, this implementation matches the error tolerances of the DART example, which leads me to believe that the errors in the bullet implementation in #13 may not be due to floating point precision.

Also note that I did not create collision shapes. They didn’t seem necessary for the simple demonstration we’re aiming for and Bullet seems to work fine without them.

This builds on the double pendulum example using bullet in pull request #13. This example uses btMultiBody, which uses generalized coordinates for representing rigid bodies and Featherstone’s algorithm for simulation.

Note that I changed the test for quaternion equality to check if the dot product of the quaternions is ±1. Otherwise, this implementation matches the error tolerances of the DART example, which leads me to believe that the errors in the bullet implementation in #13 may not be due to floating point precision.
